ELEMENTARY!!!
Compass elementary students should plan to begin the school day at 8:50 a.m. beginning September 8, 2020. This adjustment was approved by the Compass School Board in a decision at the June 11 monthly meeting and helps account for adjustments needed as the elementary and secondary programs begin to share the new facility located at 4667 W. Aviator Street in Meridian, ID. Dismissal times for elementary students will remain the same: 2:30 p.m. on Mondays and 3:30 p.m. Tuesdays through Fridays. Bus schedules will accommodate the adjusted start time. The secondary start and end times are NOT affected by this adjustment.

Administration and staff look forward to a successful upcoming year.

We gave educators almost no notice. We asked them to completely redesign what school looks like and in about 24 hours local administrators and teachers "Apollo 13'ed" the problem and fixed it. Kids learning, children being fed, needs being met in the midst of a global crisis.
No state agency did this, no so-called national experts on curriculum. The local educators fixed it in hours. HOURS.
In fact, existing state and federal policies actually created multiple roadblocks. Local schools figured out how to do it around those too. No complaining and no handwringing - just solutions and amazingly clever plans.
Remember that the next time someone tries to convince you that schools are better run by mandates from non-educators. Remember that the next time someone tells you that teachers have it easy or try to persuade you that educators are not among the smartest, most ingenious people in society. And please never say to me again, "Those who can't do anything else just go into teaching."
Get out of the way of a teacher and watch with amazement at what really happens.

One of our families has started this foundation to help raise more awareness for Metastatic Breast Cancer. Please consider participating.
October is National Breast Cancer Awareness month and while the pink ribbon waves, the reality is that 113 women die each day from Metastatic Breast Cancer and that statistic has remained the same for the past 40 years because most breast cancer funding goes to finding the disease not to finding a cure. We are trying to change that statistic and help women who live with this disease to live longer.
